summary: Feature request to add saga pattern implementation to the Ruby SDK, similar to other Temporal SDKs. The maintainers declined, explaining that sagas are a pattern rather than a utility, and different use cases require different approaches.
userImpact: Users can implement saga patterns directly in their workflows using standard Temporal APIs rather than relying on a built-in utility.
rootCause: Saga is a pattern rather than a universal utility - different users need different compensation strategies (concurrent vs sequential, different error handling approaches).
proposedFix: Implement saga pattern manually in workflow code using activity sequencing and exception handling, as shown in the maintainer's example.
workaround: Use manual compensation activity sequencing with try-rescue blocks, as demonstrated in the maintainer's code example.
resolutionDetails: Not planned as a built-in utility because the pattern is already supported through standard SDK capabilities. Pattern will instead be demonstrated in samples.
keyQuote: saga is a pattern more than a utility...different people need different approaches (e.g. some want compensations concurrently, some want to collect compensation errors in different ways)
